Fields.DialogueText: Marat? Where are you?
Kapitan! Ya zdes'!
From your expression, I'd guess that's not the end of it.

Fields.MenuText: What do we need?
More medical personnel?
What's the current size of your sick bay?

Fields.DialogueText: I have in mind some new technology, Captain. But I am still ironing out the details.
I wouldn't say no, Kapitan, but space constraints could become an issue.
I'm afraid it might be too small for what I have in mind. It requires more thought.
Okay, I'll leave you to it. Report back when you have some concrete proposals and we'll see what we can do.
Est! Right after we plan how we will defeat these Morganas.
Do you think our sick bay can handle the load?
We've made do before, Kapitan, but there is only one way to find out. I'll do my best not to have to.
@BATTLE
That's correct. I think it's time to make some changes to my sick bay. I think a few innovations could save lives.
Honestly, this ship is starting to feel like a ghost town...
Sorry to be hard to find! I was in sick bay, and one thing led to another. I ended up taking an inventory of our medical supplies.
Kapitan, I am back with my preliminary report!
And?
In short, Kapitan, I propose expanding the infirmary slightly and... attempting to create and maintain an on-ship blood bank.
Huh. Okay, what would we need in practice? Equipment, facilities...

Fields.MenuText: Aren't there blood types?
How much room do we need to expand blood storage capacities?
Right. Are you a vampire?

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan, this would require inventorying who has what type of blood. Giving someone the wrong blood type would be a grave mistake.
I hope the refrigeration needs will be relatively modest, Kapitan.
Nyet, nyet, Kapitan. Look, we are in the daylight right now. Don't be dissuaded by folklore.
Okay, a new blood bank. I'm not totally convinced we need it, but I can see the value as a kind of pilot program. Anything else?
More lighting!
Right.
Oh, while the cow is out, we also need another surgery table too. We have the medical staff to justify it, and it would mean less wait time for the crew. And then we'd need another surgery light...
When you're finished with your list, get back to me.
*ALARM*
Hopefully you'll be finished by the time this battle is over.
Challenge accepted, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
Even assuming we had cooperative volunteers on shore, we would need supplies to preserve, transport and store blood... and a way to collect blood on board.
A what, now?
A blood bank. A supply of blood that we can transfuse into sailors who...
Who've lost potentially catastrophic amounts of their own blood, yes. Sorry, I understand the principle. It's just... on a ship?
I mean, there's the refrigeration and storage required. There's the question of where you get the blood - do you have a hundred crew members tap a vein every week?
And, just as a practical matter, is massive blood loss so common that we can't just rely on on-the-spot transfusions from other crew members?
All good questions, Kapitan!
I believe I have a workable plan for refrigeration and storage. I'll show you the plans when they're finished.
As for where you get the blood - in a way, that's the heart of what I'm getting at here.
I mean, not in a literal sense. I'm not proposing a disembodied heart pumping blood in the infirmary.
Thank you for that.
No, crew members would make donations, but what I'd like to do is solicit blood drives in the ports we visit.
Civilians can contribute directly to our efforts against the enemy, and I like to think it will help bring all the nations together - if just a tiny bit.
After all, people will know they're supporting Soviets, British, Germans... you're all human.
With the latest technology, blood can remain viable for a week at a time - so for missions that keep us away from port for extended periods it's probably not viable. But for coastal patrols...
Are you in here, Marat?
Privet! Here I am, Kap...
AHH! You gave me a scare! Turn on the lights, will you?

Fields.MenuText: Now why would you do a thing like that?
What is this room?
Dark room, no lights. Are you sure you're not secretly a vampire?

Fields.DialogueText: I am going to upgrade the lighting, Kapitan. This will be part of the new sick bay expansion. It's hard to expand the hull, but it's easier to just rearrange things.
This is my room, Kapitan. I thought the space would be best suited for sickbay.
Why are you fixated on this folklore, Kapitan? I've never heard of such a tale as seafaring vampires. Do they even exist?
This is going to be quite the overhaul, isn't it?

Fields.MenuText: I don't want a protagonist struggle. There is plenty of that as is.
How many chapters do we need? This isn't War and Peace.
While we are on the topic of books, who is your favorite author?

Fields.DialogueText: The brightest light is best seen when it is dark out, Kapitan.
Oh! Have you read it? I do love the works of Tolstoy - and I understand I would probably like James Joyce as well. Isn't it exciting to put one's passion into a classic?
It is hard to pin down just one, Kapitan. There are many, and different circumstances bring different ones closer to my heart.
Can you prioritize getting lights back in here? I don't want anybody injured.
Oh, right. People can't see in the dark.
*ALARM*
Bozhe moy! There, I've got you. Hold on to me.
We have Morganas to fight. Let's get out of here. Carefully.
@BATTLE
Then where are you going to sleep?
I still haven't worked out those details yet, Kapitan. Maybe a cozy bread box will do the job?
I took out all the lights, Kapitan, so turning them on is not a possibility.
It's what usually happens, Kapitan. Everything changes, and by the time you get used to the change, it changes again. It is like a book with many short stories, and all quick reads.
*THUD*
Ow! Why aren't there any lights in this room?
Focus, Marat. Please.
Here we are - Amsterdam. So what's on your shopping list?
I am on the hunt for medical journals and books, Kapitan. So far much has been discovered, especially in the United States. Newly published print will help us determine what we need.
I thought you had already determined that by the time you started ripping out lights.

Fields.MenuText: Couldn't you have done that before you ripped out the lights?
What about drawings? You could have made a drawing.
If you say so. What is there to do in this town?

Fields.DialogueText: I needed to see the room in a whole new light, Kapitan. This required removing the old lights. Out with the old and in with the new. Pull off the bandage in one fast motion.
I am not very good at drawing, Kapitan. How is your artistic skill?
Everything, once upon a time. However, because of the war, I am not sure what there is to do - other than visiting the medical college libraries.
Okay, set that aside for now. How many medical journals do you intend to get?
All of them.
*ALARM*
I wonder - does the enemy have time to read journals, assuming they've learned the language?
I think that's a question we save for another day.
@BATTLE
That was only the catalyst to start the process, Kapitan. With a clean canvas before you, it is easy to see which colors you need to apply.
You probably think that's a kind of hyperbolic exaggeration and I just mean a large sum.
Nyet. I literally mean all of them. Every single thing my agents can find. Leave no stone unturned.
What're you reading so intently there, Marat?
I'm reading about the technique Bernard Fantus used to preserve blood in 1937.
Don't take this the wrong way, but I would hope that would mean a lot of the blood you plan to stockpile would go bad before it could be used.

Fields.MenuText: Noted. Are the lights fixed yet?
Where do we get the necessary equipment?
You gamble?

Fields.DialogueText: I got distracted by the journals, Kapitan. We will have to draw up plans for new lights. Just avoid that room for the time being.
We can order many of the supplies through the Moscow Hospital. Then we wait for them to be delivered to the docks at Leningrad.
I am looking at this in terms of risk management, Kapitan, which involves some gambling on the outcomes.
Looks like you really are taking this infirmary upgrade seriously. I look forward to seeing how the results come together.
Da, Kapitan. It will be a new chapter I can write in my own book.
The list continues to grow.
And the Morganas still continue to appear. Your list will have to wait, Kapitan.
@BATTLE
It's a gamble, Kapitan. If you don't use the blood, it will turn toxic. But if you don't have blood on hand, you lose trained crew. We need to hedge our bets.
I probably should've guessed.
According to this journal, he used a 2% solution of sodium citrate. This gave the blood a shelf life of 10 days.
Oh! Lights! I need to check if the wiring gauge and circuit load can handle new lights.
You've moved on from the journals, I see. What are you reading now?

Fields.MenuText: Where is blood usually drawn from?
What's the difference between a vein and an artery?
How many blood types are there?

Fields.DialogueText: Blood is usually drawn from the median cubital vein. However, when needed, other veins can be used in a pinch.
Veins have deoxygenated blood, and return that to the pulmonary system. Arteries have oxygenated blood and go from the pulmonary system to the body.
There are four main blood types: A, B, AB, and O. Though there are some... qualifications.
Heh. Well done.
Education is the most valuable asset one can have, Kapitan. The wrong blood type can't be given to a person, or else they will die. Knowing the finer details of phlebotomy can save lives.
Oh, wait! Let me tell you more about blood!
Uh... sure?
There are actually more blood types than we used to think!
Another time. But, for our purposes, how many blood types would that be in total?
At least eight, Kapitan.
That seems like a lot.
I wonder if there's a Dewey Decimal system for blood types. What type of Dewey Decimal System would there be for Morganas?
*ALARM*
Let's categorize them after they're sunk.
@BATTLE
A book on venipuncture and another one on modern phlebotomy, Kapitan. It's always a good idea to learn as much as I can if we are going to install a blood bank on my ship.
I'm tempted to quiz you.
By all means - preuspevat'!
Karl Landsteiner, who discovered the first four blood types, and his partner Alexander S. Wiener are now making new advancements on things called Rhesus proteins, which...
Sorry. You probably don't have time for a talk about antigens.
What's all this mess?! Strange rubber strips strewn carelessly everywhere, crew members lined up...
Marat is requesting that all crew members have their blood typed. Captain.
Marat, care to bring me up to speed?
As to what I'm doing now - if we type the blood of each crew member, then we can match it to the right blood when we make the blood bank.
Wait. You're going to type the blood of a thousand-plus crew members yourself? We don't have the refrigeration units in yet, right? Do you even have sterile needles for that many?

Fields.MenuText: I really, really don't like needles, Marat.
Sure. Needles excite me.
Not a good time, Marat. I've got to get to the bridge.

Fields.DialogueText: Needles aren't scary, Kapitan. What if you need a transfusion? A little pain now can be worth it later.
I will remember that, Kapitan! Spasibo!
Ya ponimayu. I can draw your blood after your duties are complete.
*ALARM*
Such a shame. Look at the viscosity on this lovely sample of blood. This could be you, you know.
Seriously - are you sure you're not a vampire?
@BATTLE
No, no, no. We're doing it in waves - and I have needles enough for the current group.
Lieutenant! What's going on on my deck?
Ah. Yeah, I should have seen that coming. Thank you.
Captain.
Just making sure we have accurate medical records, Kapitan. I'm sure you know that a lot of the current crew joined in hurried circumstances.
Now, please, come sit down. I need to get your blood as well, and it's best if the crew sees you do it early.
Have a seat and I'll be with you after I finish with these gentlemen.
Kapitan, I have a list!
What's the list for? Did you type everyone's blood already?
Nyet, Kapitan. I still need to type your blood, for one thing.
Duly noted. So what's the list for, then?
The list is for all of our equipment. First we need to upgrade my power capacity to handle the load of the new refrigeration units and the lighting.
Upgrade the breakers to a higher amperage... it's going to be a challenge.
The refrigeration units are coming from America. The new lighting is coming from the one optics company in Germany that begins with the letter zed.
Wow, the Zed company! That name alone determines the price.

Fields.MenuText: Are you an inventor now?
I somehow feel you've been paid to advertise for one of these companies...
Are radio waves part of the next project on your list, then?

Fields.DialogueText: I should consider it, Kapitan! I do like to work with my hands.
What do I need with money? I am very passionate and excited about the possibilities, Kapitan!
Da, Kapitan! I really would like a Hammarlund radio one day.
I will continue the list once we have dealt with the Neizvestniy Flot, Kapitan. It is always best to stay at least one step ahead of them.
@BATTLE
Be serious, Kapitan. I expect nothing but the best equipment for so delicate an endeavor.
I know the maxim "a poor carpenter blames her tools," and I want it to be irrelevant. I want the finest tools I can hold, and on my own head be the consequences.
This is the twentieth century - the age of wonders and dynamos and spoken words carried by radio waves! Let's embrace it!
Kapitan, there have been many breakthroughs in blood research in recent years. Not only typing blood, but also thinning blood as well.
And you have a stack of journals to prove it?
I do! Hold on, give me a minute and I'll find some of them for you. I just... need to find the right stack.
That's an impressive collection you have there.

Fields.MenuText: How are you able to get books and journals outside of the ship?
Play any chess lately?
What books won't you read?

Fields.DialogueText: Wheedling. Bold, relentless, and unapologetic wheedling.
I've been too busy trying to upgrade the ship, Kapitan. Perhaps once everything settles.
That's a good question, Kapitan! I try to give every book a fair chance before I decide if I like it or not. I guess the answer is none, if I give them a fighting chance?
Okay, I hate to caffeinate you and run, but I ought to get to the bridge. I need to figure out if we have to make for port soon.
And I believe I've secured a construction crew as well!
A construction crew?
Da, Kapitan! We don't have time to install everything ourselves if our objective is to find and defeat the Neizvestniy Flot.
I can't argue with that.
Can you argue with the fact that the Neizvestniy Flot are coming into range?
Can I?
It is silly to argue with empirical data, Kapitan.
@BATTLE
I've been trying to get my hands on as many as I can every time we're in port.
Marat? I hope I'm not intruding - I just thought some coffee might make the reading go more quickly.
Spasibo! You are much too kind.
... But it's not hot.
Yeah. Sorry. I may mean well, but I can only get around this ship so quickly.
I'm still very grateful. Have a seat... if you can find a chair without clutter on it. Here, let me....
Relax. I'm fine. Just tell me what you've been up to. Learn anything interesting?
Ha!
And, of course, the kindness of my friends. Yourself very much included.
Oh! If the port in question is Leningrad, I'm all for it!
Your equipment is in?
Da!

Fields.MenuText: Have you ever noticed that you never ask, but always tell?
Life-changing or life-threatening?
What is this one important thing?

Fields.DialogueText: If I always have something important to tell, then I'll always be heard, Kapitan.
Oh, the former, of course! We are in no danger. Though I suppose the latter could be construed as life-changing.
I never said it was just one important thing. It could be an amalgam of many important things stated in a singular reference.
Okay, what is it you need to tell me?
You still haven't gotten your blood drawn yet, Kapitan.
I'm not the only one, am I? Wasn't there a disappearing ensign you had to track down?
I got him in the end! I find that he only mysteriously vanishes once you break eye contact. As long as you look right at him, he stays where he's put.
So how did you get him looking in your eyes in the first place?
It... might have been while I was engaged in a private affair, Kapitan.
Exactly what sort of private affair?
Oh, look - the Morganas are at our heels, Kapitan.
Morganas are closing in, Captain!
Ha–ha! See, this was the type of private affair I was talking about - us running into each other to say the same thing before a fight!
That's a private affair?
It is when you're trying to keep your secrets and strategies from nosy opponents.
@BATTLE
Kapitan, I have something important to tell you.
... Actually, it when I was reading a magazine about chess.
*ALARM*
What are you doing on the floor, Marat?
I am taking measurements, Kapitan. I am seeing how the footprints of the refrigeration units will fit into this room.
Okay, the subject is plural in that statement. Are we getting multiple units?

Fields.MenuText: Where are you storing all your needles?
Shouldn't you have a pressure sterilizer?
What is the area of the room going to be once finished?

Fields.DialogueText: Needles are being kept in the same closet as suture needles, Kapitan. They cannot be pressure sterilized along with the cutting blades.
Da, Kapitan! Part of the plan is getting a unit from the American Sterilizer Company.
It's hard to quantify until I've made the final decisions on the equipment, Kapitan. I'm confident the work will be manageable, though.
Once we settle on what refrigeration units we are getting, we can tell the construction crew exactly what we need.
This remodeling business is very demanding.
Which is the reason I enjoy it, Kapitan! Lots of fine details which cannot be missed.
Changing the subject slightly, I just have to ask - have you found a place to put all these books you're accumulating?
Not yet, Kapitan. One project at a time.
*ALARM*
With an exception made for the Morganas. Defeating them always takes priority.
@BATTLE
Da, Kapitan. I just haven't chosen our provider. I've written to several hospitals and manufacturers. I am looking for specific models which can fit into this already small floor plan.
Granted, that does play to your strengths.
... Maybe we need a triage chart for where our attention should be allocated. I'll have to think about that.
Kapitan! I have found the models!
The refrigeration units?
Da, Kapitan! I am ordering two united from an American company who has efficient units. These are much easier to get than anything we have in the Soviet Union.
How do they work?
With chlorofluorocarbons. Are you familiar with the principles behind vapor-compression refrigeration? They're very interesting!

Fields.MenuText: It sounds like you're quite the economist.
I'm continually amazed by how much energy you put into these projects. It's damn impressive.
And here I thought refrigerators were just to store your ice in.

Fields.DialogueText: It is good to be efficient in any situation, Kapitan.
Well, I get energy back from them too!
Oh, the classic "ice boxes" have been rendered obsolete by new technology, Kapitan. Granted, many areas across the globe are now just getting electricity, so they still have their place.
Regardless, I've already ordered the units. It is more efficient to order them and then tell you rather than tell you and then order them. We pick them up in Leningrad along with everything else.
Who is this more efficient for, me or you?
If we get top of the line units for half the price, then everyone benefits. Tsel' opravdyvayet sredstva.
*ALARM*
Our trip to Leningrad might be delayed.
I won't let the Neizvestniy Flot stand in my way, Kapitan. It would be inefficient.
@BATTLE
For the same price as a unit which doesn't utilize chlorofluorocarbons, we can order two of the ones that do. This is a good method of cost–benefits, Kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: I am familiar, and I agree. It's amazing what clever people can do with the second law of thermodynamics.
I'm not familiar. If you can walk me through it when I have more time, I'd be grateful.
I'm not familiar with it, and I don't want that ever to change.

Fields.DialogueText: Ochen' khorosho skazano! I salute you, Kapitan!
Of course, the most important point right now is this...
I would be delighted.
You're joking with me, surely.
It looks like a warehouse in here!
I still haven't opened all the crates yet, Kapitan!
Are you over there, Marat? I can't see you behind these stacks of pallets. Uff! Hey! Watch where you're going!
My apologies, Captain.
Just maintaining eye contact.
Kapitan, tell the ensign I have a list of additional items for him to get in the city.
Ensign, I take it you... hey, where did he disappear to?

Fields.MenuText: Vampire lore, comically appearing officers... what has this ship gotten into?
And I respect that. But he never got the list.
Have we ruled out the possibility that he's a ghost?

Fields.DialogueText: These are the tolls a ship must take on during war. Imagine the story we can tell later about this chapter in our lives. The Ballad of the Blood-Collecting Belle...
I would bet, additionally, that he will appear when I give the task to another officer. There needs to be an epigram for this.
Find out if he can whistle - some folklore suggests that ghosts can't.
Somehow you always have the most amazing answer to any question I ask.
Kapitan, why are your cheeks turning red? You're not having blood pressure difficulties, are you?
*ALARM*
If I wasn't before, I am now. We have work to do!
@BATTLE
My postulate on the subject would be... to a place where it would be ironically funny.
They're only facts, Kapitan.
No. They're really not. They're aspects of your passion.
Well... I just enjoy talking to you. I think that gets away from me sometimes.
I'm not complaining.
... Sir? Everything all right?
Marat?
Da! They are the construction workers we picked up in Leningrad, Kapitan. They are working an honest job for an honest pay.
What's the honest pay?
We will drop them off in the Porte de Chocola... Calais.
That does seem like an honest trade.
Porte de Calais seems like such a nice area. And across the channel is Dover Castle!
What about that one we passed in the Gulf of Naples? Aragonese.

Fields.MenuText: I should have known there'd be a poet involved somewhere.
Listen, if you're interested, maybe we can map out coastal castles you can see. It's not like fortifications along the sealine are unheard of.
And the one off the coast of Normandy?

Fields.DialogueText: You make it sound like I'm obsessed - but Romantic poets from Imperial Russia are my real specialty. I know Virgil better as a character from Dante's work than as a writer.
What an excellent idea, Kapitan! It almost has a romantic aura to it.
Mont Saint-Michel? That was a spectacular sight!
*ALARM*
We will have to plan castle-hunting later, Kapitan. The Morganas are almost in range.
@BATTLE
Ah! The very castle the poet Virgil visited!
Kapitan! Privet!
I couldn't help but notice the civilian traffic belowdecks. I assume this is all going according to plan?
... Did you clear that with Moscow?
I thought it best not to bother the admirals with the details. Our contacts in France swear that our friends here will be given proper papers and opportunities to work in port.
I don't get to see many castles from the ship.
All this noise! So hard to hear myself even think!
WHAT DID YOU SAY, KAPITAN?
THERE'S A LOT OF NOISE! WE ARE SHOUTING!
WHERE DID YOU FIND LOST BOYS POUTING?
OKAY!! Here, we'll talk in this room, it's not as loud.
Est!
How long is construction going to take?

Fields.MenuText: I hope they won't be like this all day and night. A captain has to sleep sometime.
Do you think they'd work faster if we threatened them with floggings?
Okay. Let's change the subject - if you could visit any castle, which would it be?

Fields.DialogueText: I don't know, Kapitan. Maybe the crew doesn't have to sleep. Maybe there really are vampires on board this ship.
That is an interesting proposal, Kapitan. I'm afraid the ship is lacking a full complement of whips and lashes, though, and I don't think rope has the same threatening aura.
Easy - that would be the Castello di Sammezzano. It has an ornate and colorful peacock room. Technicolor photographs make the room look nothing short of beautiful.
*ALARM*
Morganas? I hope this doesn't delay the construction crew.
Conversely, it could give them all the incentive they need to finish quickly.
@BATTLE
As long as it needs to, Kapitan. Even Rome wasn't built in a day.
The construction continues, Kapitan!
So I've heard.
Be strong, Kapitan - we have come so far. Before you realize it, the new sick bay will be done.
You know, your optimism is downright bewitching.
Oh? Care to elaborate, Kapitan?
I... Well...
Morganas are ahead, Captain!
Ensign! Your timing is, as always, exceptional.
@BATTLE
I wonder what the construction crew thinks of all these battles with Morganas?
They haven't slowed down. I'm not sure they even notice the shooting.

Fields.MenuText: I know. And I know they notice the shooting. What I should have said was that I'm proud of them. We do not stop, and we do not scare.
Either that or they're desperate to get that sick bay done in case they need it.
Plus they want to be done by the time we get to Calais.

Fields.DialogueText: Kapitan! That sounds very poetic - you should write that down before you forget.
Don't make me laugh in front of civilians! I have a reputation to maintain!
Da. That too.
I'm sure they do - just as I'm sure that some have been through quite a bit back home, Kapitan. But they believe in this fight, and they trust us to win it.
Is the infirmary done yet? We have injured.
I know - it's under control. We are using the galley as sick bay at the moment.
Please don't contaminate our milk, Marat.

Fields.MenuText: Sorry - we're supposed to be in sight of another Morgana group within the hour, and I've got to get to the bridge. Get our mystery ensign to help.
I can't - I'm just here for a last-minute snack before battle. Um... want some marble rye bread?
I can't stay for more than a few minutes, but tell me how I can help.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm afraid the officer in question will only make an appearance when his sense of comedic timing demands it.
I love a marble rye, Kapitan! Though it will help to keep the injured crew in high spirits if we share it with them.
That's very kind, Kapitan - but if you need to go, I don't want to...
*ALARM*
Time to get other trained crew members to take care of the injured, Marat. Other duties call.
Da, Kapitan. With persistence we can defeat the Morganas.
@BATTLE
Help me triage these injured crew members, Kapitan. The ones which require the most attention are seen first, and we go down the list from there.
You... don't look totally unhappy with that.
Actually, it's exciting! The improvising, the making do - I feel like a veterinarian in a barn treating a prized cow.
What's that sound?
What sound?
Listen...
I don't hear anything.
Exactly! It's quiet. Is construction done?
Mostly done, Kapitan. I still need to go procure blood.
So you're not starting with collecting from the crew?
I thought about that. But then I realized that if they went into battle with a low blood supply, it could do more damage than the good the blood bank would bring.
So what's the next step?
Well, I've typed and documented all the blood of the crew - with one glaringly captainly exception.
My plan is to type and take blood from locals next time we are in port. With the inventory I need already at hand, it will take less time.
Wait, you're bringing them here? I thought it was going to be a drive through local hospitals or something.

Fields.MenuText: Isn't there a saying about bewaring warships bearing treats?
You're just saying that so we'll make more rye loaves.
Well, we'll find out soon enough.

Fields.DialogueText: I think you've read a different translation of the Iliad than the one I know.
Most of the crew enjoy it, Kapitan!
Da. If all goes well, we should be at Calais by morning.
*ALARM*
If we can battle Morganas time and time again, poking people with pointy objects in the name of patriotic purpose isn't a particularly intimidating venture.
@BATTLE
You have to admit, it sounds like a trap Odysseus might've set.
I never seem to get any, so I'll take you at your word.
It would certainly be nice to wake up to.
Word of mouth, I should think. What comrade wouldn't want to support this great patriotic war? We can also offer some bread and sweets to sweeten the deal.
That... came out awkwardly. Did it make sense to anyone but me?
Sure.
That was my original thought! But if we can manage it, it's easier to bring the people here than to refrigerate and transport the blood by auto, Kapitan.
So how are you going to get people to go out of their way to come here and have their veins tapped?
I feel like I should make a "picked a peck of pickled peppers" joke, but I should probably just get to the bridge.
If anyone asks, I'll say you made the joke and it was delightful.
How splendid it feels to finally be in France! Such a vibrant culture - the art, the history, the food...
I'm sure you've been reading up.
I can tell you that the Louvre was opened during the French Revolution to display the nation's captured artwork.
No! It was stolen?
Da! In 1913 the painting was discovered when a former worker was trying to sell it. It is rumored that it might not even be the real painting.
Huh. I have to give the perpetrators credit for daring, if not good sense. It can't be easy to traffic in paintings as famous as that.
The theft is actually a big part of why the painting is famous, Kapitan. It focused the public's attention.
The construction crew has been offloaded, Captain.
Ensign, before you head out, please go down to the chocolatier and bring me back a box. No! Get two boxes and I'll share half of one with you.
Yes, miss!

Fields.MenuText: You're certain they're still willing to be poked like a pig on a spit?
How much chocolate do you need?
Have you seen that crate of pumpernickel bread?

Fields.DialogueText: We have bread and cookies to give as a token of our appreciation. The bread is pumpernickel.
I require highly refined fuel to help my mind plan out the finer details, Kapitan.
Da, Kapitan, it's going to be allocated to give to donors in exchange for some blood. Bread for blood.
*ALARM*
We'd best be off, then!
Not without my chocolate, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
It was really our last chance to secure this kind of treat. From here it's back off to Leningrad to solicit help from the people of the city.
Not as much as I'd like. The sick bay work, you know...
Oh, I understand completely. But I bet you still know more than I do.
Just the usual stray details, Kapitan.
Oh, and did you know that the Mona Lisa was stolen in 1911 and an innocent person was wrongly accused of the theft?
If you have anything to say, say it fast, Marat. I've got eye contact.
Well played.
Spasibo. And thank you for your assistance.
Technically, it's back to Leningrad to investigate reports of increasing Morgana activity. But I take your point. It is a good place to launch the blood drive.

Fields.MenuText: I never thought anyone could make blood talk cute.
Sorry to interrupt, but - is there any pumpernickel left?
That's genuinely impressive. Let's just hope we don't need it.

Fields.DialogueText: Kapitan, talking of blood, you are making it rush to my cheeks...
I'm afraid the pumpernickel was distributed. We soviets love our rye bread. I am sure some of similar or superior quality can be easily obtained.
Ya soglasna. And, of course, the true challenge will come from refreshing the stockpile on more or less a weekly basis.
Well, let's get this grand tour of the new sick bay, then.
Da, Kapitan! Here is the pressure sterilizer where we sterilize most tools. Cutting tools go into a container of disinfecting liquid. And here is where we put sterilized surgical packs.
Now if you'll follow me, here are our two hydraulic surgery tables. Instructions are on the foot pedals. And here are our refrigeration units.
Very impressive! This area is much larger.
Da, Kapitan! Sacrificing my room to make the sick bay larger means we can handle twice the load. It's very bright in this room. A bright room makes it easier to keep clean.
You shouldn't have had to give up your room.
This expansion of sick bay has been a goal of mine, Kapitan. Hard work and sacrifice must be made for the betterment of the ship and the mission.
In no time you will wonder how we managed before sick bay was expanded and overhauled.
*ALARM*
I hope we don't have to christen sick bay so early.
@BATTLE
Kapitan, look at all the blood I have collected! Two refrigeration units are filled to the brim.
The new sick bay is very bright and well lit, Kapitan. It makes everything go so much easier and more efficiently.
While we're on the topic of making things easier - where are you going to put all your journals and books? Have you picked a place?
Not yet, Kapitan - it's the most awkward part about giving up my personal quarters.
So you have enough to fill a small library now and you expect that to... what, double if we're still out here in a year? Triple?
I hesitate to guess, Kapitan. I wonder if any officers would be willing to sacrifice their rooms.
You can ask the Disappearing Ensign if I ever find him. I need to have him run an errand for me.
Well, you know how to summon him, Kapitan! You must ask after someone's private affairs or stumble your way through a maze of construction supplies! That last one is possibly best done in the dark.
I think I'll just cast the widest net I can. So - if you see the Ensign, tell him I'm looking for him.

Fields.MenuText: How many books do you have?
How many books do you have on chess alone?
How many medical books do you have?

Fields.DialogueText: It's hard to quantify the number exactly, Kapitan.
I would have to say not nearly enough, Kapitan.
Not as many as I would like to have, Kapitan.
I know the collection is... a bit unwieldy, but please believe me when I say it is integral to the ship's performance.
@BATTLE
Da, Kapitan!
And my collection is only growing. There have been so many advances in medical technology in the past two years alone!
Okay. Stepping back a bit - I'm sorry, but I have to ask...
You don't have to sell me on it. It would be a fantastic resource even if it didn't make you happy.
We'll figure out a place for it. And I'll pitch in however I can.
I know you will, Kapitan. Spasibo.
Thank me after the fight.
*ALARM*
Ah, then too!
Kapitan! What's that noise?
Which noise? The boiler knocking?
Nyet, Kapitan. It's not my boiler knocking, I know what that feels like. This sounds more like hammers and saws. I thought the construction crew left?
Maybe it's the wind? An atmospheric Calypso singing in your ear?
Captain, this doesn't seem like your usual self. Here you are going on about mythical sea nymphs.
In fairness, I think in any Odyssey metaphor, I'd be the Odysseus and you'd be Athena. With Obukhovskii 12"/52 Pattern guns. I think I'm fairly well watched over.

Fields.MenuText: Hey, look at the time! With your sick bay done, why don't you play a game of chess?
Did you ever get your chocolate?
Did we lose any blood in the refrigerator yet?

Fields.DialogueText: What if I want to play chess with that mysterious Calypso?
I haven't seen the ensign since we left Leningrad. I hope it didn't disappear into the ether!
Good idea, Kapitan. I'll have to go take inventory.
*ALARM*
Do you think this noise was from the Morganas?
To quote my favorite goddess of wisdom - certainly not outside the realm of possibilities.
@BATTLE
The Calypso is busy. Find that officer instead.
Seems unlikely - though you might have to best the man in a game of chess to reclaim your chocolate.
Yes, go do that! I'll find where this noise is coming from.
Maybe I shouldn't rule out nymph activity. Certainly not outside the realm of possibilities - perhaps an outlier.
And Calypso kept Odysseus on her island for seven years. That doesn't seem like a precedent you should take lightly.
First Comrade, the Captain requests your presence. If you'd be so kind as to follow me?
I wonder what it could be for? I hope I haven't done anything wrong.
Surprise!
Ticker tape? What is this, Kapitan?
What we have here is a library - with a place for all your current books and a whole lot of space for future acquisitions.
I don't know what to say, Kapitan! I... I am too shocked, tickled, I.... What do I do?

Fields.MenuText: I would just enjoy it - take it in.

Fields.DialogueText: But... but this was your room! Are you certain you've given up the space you wanted to give up?
Your sacrifice for the infirmary inspired me to sacrifice mine. I can make do with smaller quarters.
All these lovely built-in shelves! Is that what the "Calypso" noise was?
Yeah, I had the Ensign secretly hire a crew to build everything. Thankfully, you're good at tuning out the world when you're reading....
Oh! I need to make a card catalog as well! This is wonderful!
*ALARM*
The Morganas! Let's go take care of them before they destroy my exquisite new library!
@BATTLE
It's so wonderful! It's...
Oh, look, the books are all out of order.
Yeah, I'm sorry about that. We brought them here in a hurry, and... well, I suppose you have a new project now, like it or not.
... But I really hope you like it.
Kapitan, I'm ready for this one. The Dewey Decimal System needs to be implemented here, and I'm the Belle to do it.
You'll have to drag me out of here, Kapitan!

Fields.MenuText: Read?
Lots of reorganization. I've just laid the groundwork.

Fields.DialogueText: Straight to the heart of the matter as always, Kapitan.
Never sell yourself short, Kapitan. You've given me exactly what I need!
Kapitan, look! A chess board!
I thought you could benefit from it.
It's... what, mahogany and yew? It's so lovely!
I'm very pleased to see that you are enjoying this.
I am beyond merely enjoying it, Kapitan. Care to play a game?
Sure!

Fields.MenuText: With how badly you beat me, how can I forget?
Ask me that again after my inevitable triumph.
Objective of the game is to take both rooks, right?

Fields.DialogueText: I often can't help it, Kapitan. I see a good strategy and I must follow through. Would you expect any less of me?
Oh, Kapitan. It's good to see your delusions make you happy.
I sincerely hope that you are joking, Kapitan!
Am I white, then?
Da. Why not? You move first, Kapitan, which means in this game you have the advantage.
*ALARM*
Oh, no! Don't give the Morganas the advantage, Kapitan!
I've been trying my best this entire time.
Just remember, think of it as chess. Move with liberal consideration and always stay one step ahead of your opponent.
@BATTLE
Do you remember how to play?
@BATTLE
How did this happen? Marat, give me an honest explanation for all of this!
The only explanation is that you've beaten me at chess, Kapitan.
That's a statistical improbability and you know it.

Fields.MenuText: I think something deliberate has happened.
Are you casting aspersions on my victory, Marat? An outlier to be truncated out?
Maybe it's the board.

Fields.DialogueText: I can't say what was the symptom, but you have beaten me. Perhaps I castled too early in the game.
Nyet. No one can take this moment from you. Even if I beat you in the next seven thousand, three hundred and forty-four games in a row.
I know there's the proverb of a poor carpenter blaming their tools, but what if an adequate carpenter blames their tools? So much of the world is undiscovered.
You know what I think? What my hypothesis is?
I would love to hear it, Kapitan!
I hypothesize that you let me win for once.
Why would you say that, Kapitan?
Because you are a strategic prodigy and yet I won. You were either sleep-chessing or you let me win.
And that victory deserves a mark of recognition.
Let's hear it. I'm all ears.
And mate. I'll admit, you've castled my heart, Kapitan. Or many this is a classical opening to a romantic tale? I am honestly not sure which one it is at the moment...
You've been reading too many chess books. One of those romances might do you some good.
Perhaps one of our own writing?
Anomalies occur all the time in nature. Read some medical books and you'll soon learn about many. Most outliers in any given mass of data are truncated out.
Let's see... if I'm to extract a victory from this, I'm going to have to... no, no, perhaps here...
*ALARM*
We'll write down the board state. There's a real battle on!
I can't kiss your ears.
Check.
I have a better hypothesis. I acted in the best interest of the course of this little war, and in so doing gave you all the tools you needed for victory. As you've done for me all this time.
I think I'm a better writer than a chess player.
Chudesno. Then I look doubly forward to what we create.
